param.humanName: Use first IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates
param.name: INS5_USE
param.documentation: Use first IMU for attitude, velocity and position estimates

param.name: INS5_ACC_ID
param.documentation: Accelerometer sensor ID, taking into account its type, bus and instance

param.name: INS5_ACCSCAL_X
param.documentation: Accelerometer scaling of X axis. Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS5_ACCSCAL_Y
param.documentation: Accelerometer scaling of Y axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS5_ACCSCAL_Z
param.documentation: Accelerometer scaling of Z axis Calculated during acceleration calibration routine

param.name: INS5_ACCOFFS_X
param.documentation: Accelerometer offsets of X axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS5_ACCOFFS_Y
param.documentation: Accelerometer offsets of Y axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS5_ACCOFFS_Z
param.documentation: Accelerometer offsets of Z axis. This is setup using the acceleration calibration or level operations

param.name: INS5_POS_X
param.documentation: X position of the first IMU Accelerometer in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

param.name: INS5_POS_Y
param.documentation: Y position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

param.name: INS5_POS_Z
param.documentation: Z position of the first IMU accelerometer in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin. Attention: The IMU should be located as close to the vehicle c.g. as practical so that the value of this parameter is minimised. Failure to do so can result in noisy navigation velocity measurements due to vibration and IMU gyro noise. If the IMU cannot be moved and velocity noise is a problem, a location closer to the IMU can be used as the body frame origin.

param.name: INS_HNTC2_ENABLE
param.documentation: Harmonic Notch Filter enable

param.name: INS_HNTC2_FREQ
param.documentation: Harmonic Notch Filter base center frequency in Hz. This is the center frequency for static notches, the center frequency for Throttle based notches at the reference thrust value, and the minimum limit of center frequency variation for all other notch types. This should always be set lower than half the backend gyro rate (which is typically 1Khz).

param.name: INS_HNTC2_BW
param.documentation: Harmonic Notch Filter bandwidth in Hz. This is typically set to half the base frequency. The ratio of base frequency to bandwidth determines the notch quality factor and is fixed across harmonics.

param.name: INS_HNTC2_ATT
param.documentation: Harmonic Notch Filter attenuation in dB. Values greater than 40dB will typically produce a hard notch rather than a modest attenuation of motor noise.

param.name: INS_HNTC2_HMNCS
param.documentation: Bitmask of harmonic frequencies to apply Harmonic Notch Filter to. This option takes effect on the next reboot. A value of 0 disables this filter. The first harmonic refers to the base frequency.
param.field: 0: 1st harmonic, 1: 2nd harmonic, 2: 3rd harmonic, 3: 4th harmonic, 4: 5th harmonic, 5: 6th harmonic, 6: 7th harmonic, 7: 8th harmonic, 8: 9th harmonic, 9: 10th harmonic, 10: 11th harmonic, 11: 12th harmonic, 12: 13th harmonic, 13: 14th harmonic, 14: 15th harmonic, 15: 16th harmonic

param.name: INS_HNTC2_REF
param.documentation: A reference value of zero disables dynamic updates on the Harmonic Notch Filter and a positive value enables dynamic updates on the Harmonic Notch Filter. For throttle-based scaling, this parameter is the reference value associated with the specified frequency to facilitate frequency scaling of the Harmonic Notch Filter. For RPM and ESC telemetry based tracking, this parameter is set to 1 to enable the Harmonic Notch Filter using the RPM sensor or ESC telemetry set to measure rotor speed. The sensor data is converted to Hz automatically for use in the Harmonic Notch Filter. This reference value may also be used to scale the sensor data, if required. For example, rpm sensor data is required to measure heli motor RPM. Therefore the reference value can be used to scale the RPM sensor to the rotor RPM.

param.humanName: Harmonic Notch Filter dynamic frequency tracking mode
param.name: INS_HNTC2_MODE
param.documentation: Harmonic Notch Filter dynamic frequency tracking mode. Dynamic updates can be throttle, RPM sensor, ESC telemetry or dynamic FFT based. Throttle-based harmonic notch cannot be used on fixed wing only planes. It can for Copters, QuaadPlane(while in VTOL modes), and Rovers.

param.name: INS_HNTC2_OPTS
param.documentation: Harmonic Notch Filter options. Triple and double-notches can provide deeper attenuation across a wider bandwidth with reduced latency than single notches and are suitable for larger aircraft. Multi-Source attaches a harmonic notch to each detected noise frequency instead of simply being multiples of the base frequency, in the case of FFT it will attach notches to each of three detected noise peaks, in the case of ESC it will attach notches to each of four motor RPM values. Loop rate update changes the notch center frequency at the scheduler loop rate rather than at the default of 200Hz. If both double and triple notches are specified only double notches will take effect.

bitmask.bit: Use min freq on RPM source failure

param.field: 0:Double notch,1:Multi-Source,2:Update at loop rate,3:EnableOnAllIMUs,4:Triple notch, 5:Use min freq on RPM source failure, 6:Quintuple notch

param.name: INS_HNTC2_FM_RAT
param.documentation: The minimum ratio below the configured frequency to take throttle based notch filters when flying at a throttle level below the reference throttle. Note that lower frequency notch filters will have more phase lag. If you want throttle based notch filtering to be effective at a throttle up to 30% below the configured notch frequency then set this parameter to 0.7. The default of 1.0 means the notch will not go below the frequency in the FREQ parameter.

param.name: INS_LOG_BAT_CNT
param.documentation: Number of samples to take when logging streams of IMU sensor readings. Will be rounded down to a multiple of 32. This option takes effect on the next reboot.

param.name: INS_LOG_BAT_MASK
param.documentation: Bitmap of which IMUs to log batch data for. This option takes effect on the next reboot.

param.name: INS_LOG_BAT_OPT
param.documentation: Options for the BatchSampler.

bitmask.bit: Sensor-Rate Logging (sample at full sensor rate seen by AP)

param.field: 0:Sensor-Rate Logging (sample at full sensor rate seen by AP), 1: Sample post-filtering, 2: Sample pre- and post-filter

param.name: INS_LOG_BAT_LGIN
param.documentation: Interval between pushing samples to the AP_Logger log

param.name: INS_LOG_BAT_LGCT
param.documentation: Number of samples to push to count every INS_LOG_BAT_LGIN

param.name: KDE_NPOLE
param.documentation: Sets the number of motor poles to calculate the correct RPM value

param.name: LOG_BACKEND_TYPE
param.documentation: Bitmap of what Logger backend types to enable. Block-based logging is available on SITL and boards with dataflash chips. Multiple backends can be selected.

param.humanName: Logging File and Block Backend buffer size max (in kibibytes)
param.name: LOG_FILE_BUFSIZE
param.documentation: The File and Block backends use a buffer to store data before writing to the block device. Raising this value may reduce "gaps" in your SD card logging but increases memory usage. This buffer size may be reduced to free up available memory

param.name: LOG_DISARMED
param.documentation: If LOG_DISARMED is set to 1 then logging will be enabled at all times including when disarmed. Logging before arming can make for very large logfiles but can help a lot when tracking down startup issues and is necessary if logging of EKF replay data is selected via the LOG_REPLAY parameter. If LOG_DISARMED is set to 2, then logging will be enabled when disarmed, but not if a USB connection is detected. This can be used to prevent unwanted data logs being generated when the vehicle is connected via USB for log downloading or parameter changes. If LOG_DISARMED is set to 3 then logging will happen while disarmed, but if the vehicle never arms then the logs using the filesystem backend will be discarded on the next boot.

values.value: Discard log on reboot if never armed

param.humanName: Enable logging of information needed for Replay
param.name: LOG_REPLAY
param.documentation: If LOG_REPLAY is set to 1 then the EKF2 and EKF3 state estimators will log detailed information needed for diagnosing problems with the Kalman filter. LOG_DISARMED must be set to 1 or 2 or else the log will not contain the pre-flight data required for replay testing of the EKF's. It is suggested that you also raise LOG_FILE_BUFSIZE to give more buffer space for logging and use a high quality microSD card to ensure no sensor data is lost.

param.humanName: Stop logging to current file on disarm
param.name: LOG_FILE_DSRMROT
param.documentation: When set, the current log file is closed when the vehicle is disarmed. If LOG_DISARMED is set then a fresh log will be opened. Applies to the File and Block logging backends.

param.humanName: Maximum AP_Logger MAVLink Backend buffer size
param.name: LOG_MAV_BUFSIZE
param.documentation: Maximum amount of memory to allocate to AP_Logger-over-mavlink

param.humanName: Timeout before giving up on file writes
param.name: LOG_FILE_TIMEOUT
param.documentation: This controls the amount of time before failing writes to a log file cause the file to be closed and logging stopped.

param.humanName: Old logs on the SD card will be deleted to maintain this amount of free space
param.name: LOG_FILE_MB_FREE
param.documentation: Set this such that the free space is larger than your largest typical flight log

param.humanName: Maximum logging rate for file backend
param.name: LOG_FILE_RATEMAX
param.documentation: This sets the maximum rate that streaming log messages will be logged to the file backend. A value of zero means that rate limiting is disabled.

param.humanName: Maximum logging rate for mavlink backend
param.name: LOG_MAV_RATEMAX
param.documentation: This sets the maximum rate that streaming log messages will be logged to the mavlink backend. A value of zero means that rate limiting is disabled.

param.humanName: Maximum logging rate for block backend
param.name: LOG_BLK_RATEMAX
param.documentation: This sets the maximum rate that streaming log messages will be logged to the block backend. A value of zero means that rate limiting is disabled.

param.name: LOG_DARM_RATEMAX
param.documentation: This sets the maximum rate that streaming log messages will be logged to any backend when disarmed. A value of zero means that the normal backend rate limit is applied.

param.name: LOG_MAX_FILES
param.documentation: This sets the maximum number of log file that will be written on dataflash or sd card before starting to rotate log number. Limit is capped at 500 logs.

param.humanName: MAVLink system ID of this vehicle
param.name: MAV_SYSID
param.documentation: Allows setting an individual MAVLink system id for this vehicle to distinguish it from others on the same network.

param.name: MAV_GCS_SYSID
param.documentation: This sets what MAVLink source system IDs are accepted for GCS failsafe handling, RC overrides and manual control. When MAV_GCS_SYSID_HI is less than MAV_GCS_SYSID then only this value is considered to be a GCS. When MAV_GCS_SYSID_HI is greater than or equal to MAV_GCS_SYSID then the range of values between MAV_GCS_SYSID and MAV_GCS_SYSID_HI (inclusive) are all treated as valid GCS MAVLink system IDs

param.name: MAV_GCS_SYSID_HI
param.documentation: Upper limit of MAVLink source system IDs considered to be from the GCS. When this is less than MAV_GCS_SYSID then only MAV_GCS_SYSID is used as GCS ID. When this is greater than or equal to MAV_GCS_SYSID then the range of values from MAV_GCS_SYSID to MAV_GCS_SYSID_HI (inclusive) is treated as a GCS ID.

param.name: MAV_OPTIONS
param.documentation: Alters various behaviour of the MAVLink interface

bitmask.bit: Accept MAVLink only from system IDs given by MAV_SYSID_GCS and MAV_SYSID_GCS_HI

param.field: 0:Accept MAVLink only from system IDs given by MAV_SYSID_GCS and MAV_SYSID_GCS_HI

param.name: MAV_TELEM_DELAY
param.documentation: The amount of time (in seconds) to delay radio telemetry to prevent an Xbee bricking on power up

param.documentation: Used for average cell voltage calculation

param.name: MSP_OPTIONS
param.documentation: A bitmask to set some MSP specific options: EnableTelemetryMode-allows "push" mode telemetry when only rx line of OSD ic connected to autopilot, EnableBTFLFonts-uses indexes corresponding to Betaflight fonts if OSD uses those instead of ArduPilot fonts. EnableINAVFonts uses INAV fonts and overrides EnableBTFLFonts if that option is enabled.

param.name: NET_ENABLE
param.documentation: Networking Enable

param.name: NET_NETMASK
param.documentation: Allows setting static subnet mask. The value is a count of consecutive bits. Examples: 24 = 255.255.255.0, 16 = 255.255.0.0

param.name: NET_DHCP
param.documentation: Enable/Disable DHCP client

param.name: NET_TESTS
param.documentation: Enable/Disable networking tests
param.field: 0:UDP echo test,1:TCP echo test, 2:TCP discard test, 3:TCP reflect test

param.name: NET_OPTIONS
param.documentation: Networking options
param.field: 0:EnablePPP Ethernet gateway, 1:Enable CAN1 multicast endpoint, 2:Enable CAN2 multicast endpoint, 3:Enable CAN1 multicast bridged, 4:Enable CAN2 multicast bridged, 5:DisablePPPTimeout, 6:DisablePPPEchoLimit, 7:Capture to file

param.name: NET_P1_TYPE
param.documentation: Port type for network serial port. For the two client types a valid destination IP address must be set. For the two server types either 0.0.0.0 or a local address can be used. The UDP client type will use broadcast if the IP is set to 255.255.255.255 and will use UDP multicast if the IP is in the multicast address range.

param.name: NMEA_RATE_MS
param.documentation: NMEA Output rate. This controls the interval at which all the enabled NMEA messages are sent. Most NMEA systems expect 100ms (10Hz) or slower.

param.name: NMEA_MSG_EN
param.documentation: This is a bitmask of enabled NMEA messages. All messages will be sent consecutively at the same rate interval

param.name: NTF_LED_BRIGHT
param.documentation: Select the RGB LED brightness level. When USB is connected brightness will never be higher than low regardless of the setting.

param.name: NTF_BUZZ_TYPES
param.documentation: Controls what types of Buzzer will be enabled

param.humanName: Specifies colour source for the RGBLed
param.name: NTF_LED_OVERRIDE
param.documentation: Specifies the source for the colours and brightness for the LED. OutbackChallenge conforms to the MedicalExpress (https://uavchallenge.org/medical-express/) rules, essentially "Green" is disarmed (safe-to-approach), "Red" is armed (not safe-to-approach). Traffic light is a simplified color set, red when armed, yellow when the safety switch is not surpressing outputs (but disarmed), and green when outputs are surpressed and disarmed, the LED will blink faster if disarmed and failing arming checks.

param.name: NTF_DISPLAY_TYPE
param.documentation: This sets up the type of on-board I2C display. Disabled by default.

param.name: NTF_OREO_THEME
param.documentation: Enable/Disable Solo Oreo LED driver, 0 to disable, 1 for Aircraft theme, 2 for Rover theme

param.name: NTF_BUZZ_PIN
param.documentation: Enables to connect active buzzer to arbitrary pin. Requires 3-pin buzzer or additional MOSFET! Some the Wiki's "GPIOs" page for how to determine the pin number for a given autopilot.

param.name: NTF_LED_TYPES
param.documentation: Controls what types of LEDs will be enabled
param.field: 0:Built-in LED, 1:Internal ToshibaLED, 2:External ToshibaLED, 3:External PCA9685, 4:Oreo LED, 5:DroneCAN, 6:NCP5623 External, 7:NCP5623 Internal, 8:NeoPixel, 9:ProfiLED, 10:Scripting, 11:DShot, 12:ProfiLED_SPI, 13:LP5562 External, 14: LP5562 Internal, 15:IS31FL3195 External, 16: IS31FL3195 Internal, 17: DiscreteRGB, 18: NeoPixelRGB, 19:ProfiLED_IOMCU

param.name: NTF_BUZZ_ON_LVL
param.documentation: Specifies pin level that indicates buzzer should play

param.name: NTF_BUZZ_VOLUME
param.documentation: Control the volume of the buzzer

param.name: NTF_LED_LEN
param.documentation: The number of Serial LED's to use for notifications (NeoPixel's and ProfiLED)

param.name: RC_OVERRIDE_TIME
param.documentation: Timeout after which RC overrides will no longer be used, and RC input will resume, 0 will disable RC overrides, -1 will never timeout, and continue using overrides until they are disabled

param.name: RC_OPTIONS
param.documentation: RC input options

bitmask.bit: Ignore Receiver Failsafe bit but allow other RC failsafes if setup
Skip the arming check for neutral Roll/Pitch/Yaw sticks
Suppress CRSF mode/rate message for ELRS systems
Use Link Quality for RSSI with CRSF
Annotate CRSF flight mode with * on disarm

param.field: 0:Ignore RC Receiver, 1:Ignore MAVLink Overrides, 2:Ignore Receiver Failsafe bit but allow other RC failsafes if setup, 3:FPort Pad, 4:Log RC input bytes, 5:Arming check throttle for 0 input, 6:Skip the arming check for neutral Roll/Pitch/Yaw sticks, 7:Allow Switch reverse, 8:Use passthrough for CRSF telemetry, 9:Suppress CRSF mode/rate message for ELRS systems,10:Enable multiple receiver support, 11:Use Link Quality for RSSI with CRSF, 12:Annotate CRSF flight mode with * on disarm, 13: Use 420kbaud for ELRS protocol

param.name: RC_PROTOCOLS
param.documentation: Bitmask of enabled RC protocols. Allows narrowing the protocol detection to only specific types of RC receivers which can avoid issues with incorrect detection. Set to 1 to enable all protocols.

param.name: RC_FS_TIMEOUT
param.documentation: RC failsafe will trigger this many seconds after loss of RC

param.name: RC1_MIN
param.documentation: RC minimum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: RC1_TRIM
param.documentation: RC trim (neutral) PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: RC1_MAX
param.documentation: RC maximum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: RC1_REVERSED
param.documentation: Reverse channel input. Set to 0 for normal operation. Set to 1 to reverse this input channel.

param.name: RC1_DZ
param.documentation: PWM dead zone in microseconds around trim or bottom

param.name: RC1_OPTION
param.documentation: Function assigned to this RC channel

param.documentation: RC maximum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: RC15_REVERSED
param.documentation: Reverse channel input. Set to 0 for normal operation. Set to 1 to reverse this input channel.

param.name: RC15_DZ
param.documentation: PWM dead zone in microseconds around trim or bottom

param.name: RC15_OPTION
param.documentation: Function assigned to this RC channel

param.name: RC16_MIN
param.documentation: RC minimum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: RC16_TRIM
param.documentation: RC trim (neutral) PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: RC16_MAX
param.documentation: RC maximum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: RC16_REVERSED
param.documentation: Reverse channel input. Set to 0 for normal operation. Set to 1 to reverse this input channel.

param.name: RC16_DZ
param.documentation: PWM dead zone in microseconds around trim or bottom

param.name: RC16_OPTION
param.documentation: Function assigned to this RC channel

param.name: RCMAP_ROLL
param.documentation: Roll channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Roll is normally on channel 1, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

param.name: RCMAP_PITCH
param.documentation: Pitch channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Pitch is normally on channel 2, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

param.name: RCMAP_THROTTLE
param.documentation: Throttle channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Throttle is normally on channel 3, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

param.name: RCMAP_YAW
param.documentation: Yaw channel number. This is useful when you have a RC transmitter that can't change the channel order easily. Yaw (also known as rudder) is normally on channel 4, but you can move it to any channel with this parameter. Reboot is required for changes to take effect.

param.name: RPM1_TYPE
param.documentation: What type of RPM sensor is connected

param.name: RPM1_SCALING
param.documentation: Scaling factor between sensor reading and RPM.

param.name: RPM1_MAX
param.documentation: Maximum RPM to report. Only used on type = GPIO.

param.name: RPM1_MIN
param.documentation: Minimum RPM to report. Only used on type = GPIO.

param.name: RPM1_MIN_QUAL
param.documentation: Minimum data quality to be used

param.name: RPM1_PIN
param.documentation: Which digital GPIO pin to use. Only used on type = GPIO. Some common values are given, but see the Wiki's "GPIOs" page for how to determine the pin number for a given autopilot.

param.humanName: Bitmask of ESC telemetry channels to average
param.name: RPM1_ESC_MASK
param.documentation: Mask of channels which support ESC rpm telemetry. RPM telemetry of the selected channels will be averaged

param.humanName: ESC Telemetry Index to write RPM to
param.name: RPM1_ESC_INDEX
param.documentation: ESC Telemetry Index to write RPM to. Use 0 to disable.

param.name: RPM1_DC_ID
param.documentation: DroneCAN sensor ID to assign to this backend

param.name: RSSI_TYPE
param.documentation: Radio Receiver RSSI type. If your radio receiver supports RSSI of some kind, set it here, then set its associated RSSI_XXXXX parameters, if any.

param.name: RSSI_ANA_PIN
param.documentation: Pin used to read the RSSI voltage or PWM value. Analog Airspeed ports can be used for Analog inputs (some autopilots provide others also), Non-IOMCU Servo/MotorOutputs can be used for PWM input when configured as "GPIOs". Values for some autopilots are given as examples. Search wiki for "Analog pins" for analog pin or "GPIOs", if PWM input type, to determine pin number.

param.name: RSSI_PIN_LOW
param.documentation: RSSI pin's voltage received on the RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the weakest. Some radio receivers put out inverted values so this value may be higher than RSSI_PIN_HIGH. When using pin 103, the maximum value of the parameter is 3.3V.

param.name: RSSI_PIN_HIGH
param.documentation: RSSI pin's voltage received on the RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the strongest. Some radio receivers put out inverted values so this value may be lower than RSSI_PIN_LOW. When using pin 103, the maximum value of the parameter is 3.3V.

param.name: RSSI_CHANNEL
param.documentation: The channel number where RSSI will be output by the radio receiver (5 and above).

param.name: RSSI_CHAN_LOW
param.documentation: PWM value that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_CHANNEL or RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the weakest. Some radio receivers output inverted values so this value may be lower than RSSI_CHAN_HIGH

param.name: RSSI_CHAN_HIGH
param.documentation: PWM value that the radio receiver will put on the RSSI_CHANNEL or RSSI_ANA_PIN when the signal strength is the strongest. Some radio receivers output inverted values so this value may be higher than RSSI_CHAN_LOW

param.name: SCHED_DEBUG
param.documentation: Set to non-zero to enable scheduler debug messages. When set to show "Slips" the scheduler will display a message whenever a scheduled task is delayed due to too much CPU load. When set to ShowOverruns the scheduled will display a message whenever a task takes longer than the limit promised in the task table.

param.name: SCHED_LOOP_RATE
param.documentation: This controls the rate of the main control loop in Hz. This should only be changed by developers. This only takes effect on restart. Values over 400 are considered highly experimental.

param.name: SCHED_OPTIONS
param.documentation: This controls optional aspects of the scheduler.

param.name: SCR_ENABLE
param.documentation: Controls if scripting is enabled

param.name: SCR_VM_I_COUNT
param.documentation: The number virtual machine instructions that can be run before considering a script to have taken an excessive amount of time

param.name: SCR_HEAP_SIZE
param.documentation: Amount of memory available for scripting

param.name: SCR_DEBUG_OPTS
param.documentation: Debugging options

bitmask.bit: No Scripts to run message if all scripts have stopped
Runtime messages for memory usage and execution time
log runtime memory usage and execution time
Save CRC of current scripts to loaded and running checksum parameters enabling pre-arm
Disable heap expansion on allocation failure

param.field: 0: No Scripts to run message if all scripts have stopped, 1: Runtime messages for memory usage and execution time, 2: Suppress logging scripts to dataflash, 3: log runtime memory usage and execution time, 4: Disable pre-arm check, 5: Save CRC of current scripts to loaded and running checksum parameters enabling pre-arm, 6: Disable heap expansion on allocation failure

param.name: SCR_USER1
param.documentation: General purpose user variable input for scripts

param.name: SCR_USER2
param.documentation: General purpose user variable input for scripts

param.name: SCR_USER3
param.documentation: General purpose user variable input for scripts

param.name: SCR_USER4
param.documentation: General purpose user variable input for scripts

param.name: SCR_USER5
param.documentation: General purpose user variable input for scripts

param.name: SCR_USER6
param.documentation: General purpose user variable input for scripts

param.name: SCR_DIR_DISABLE
param.documentation: This will stop scripts being loaded from the given locations

param.name: SCR_LD_CHECKSUM
param.documentation: Required XOR of CRC32 checksum of loaded scripts, vehicle will not arm with incorrect scripts loaded, -1 disables

param.name: SCR_RUN_CHECKSUM
param.documentation: Required XOR of CRC32 checksum of running scripts, vehicle will not arm with incorrect scripts running, -1 disables

param.name: SCR_THD_PRIORITY
param.documentation: This sets the priority of the scripting thread. This is normally set to a low priority to prevent scripts from interfering with other parts of the system. Advanced users can change this priority if scripting needs to be prioritised for realtime applications. WARNING: changing this parameter can impact the stability of your flight controller. The scipting thread priority in this parameter is chosen based on a set of system level priorities for other subsystems. It is strongly recommended that you use the lowest priority that is sufficient for your application. Note that all scripts run at the same priority, so if you raise this priority you must carefully audit all lua scripts for behaviour that does not interfere with the operation of the system.

param.name: SCR_SDEV_EN
param.documentation: Enable scripting serial devices

param.humanName: Serial protocol of scripting serial device
param.name: SCR_SDEV1_PROTO
param.documentation: Serial protocol of scripting serial device

param.humanName: Serial protocol of scripting serial device
param.name: SCR_SDEV2_PROTO
param.documentation: Serial protocol of scripting serial device

param.humanName: Serial protocol of scripting serial device
param.name: SCR_SDEV3_PROTO
param.documentation: Serial protocol of scripting serial device

param.name: SERIAL0_BAUD
param.documentation: The baud rate used on the USB console. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

param.name: SERIAL0_PROTOCOL
param.documentation: Control what protocol to use on the console.

param.name: SERIAL1_PROTOCOL
param.documentation: Control what protocol to use on the Telem1 port. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

param.name: SERIAL1_BAUD
param.documentation: The baud rate used on the Telem1 port. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

param.name: SERIAL2_PROTOCOL
param.documentation: Control what protocol to use on the Telem2 port. Note that the Frsky options require external converter hardware. See the wiki for details.

param.name: SERIAL2_BAUD
param.documentation: The baud rate of the Telem2 port. Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

param.name: SERIAL3_PROTOCOL

param.name: SERIAL3_BAUD
param.documentation: The baud rate used for the Serial 3 (GPS). Most stm32-based boards can support rates of up to 1500. If you setup a rate you cannot support and then can't connect to your board you should load a firmware from a different vehicle type. That will reset all your parameters to defaults.

param.name: SERIAL4_BAUD

param.name: SERIAL1_OPTIONS
param.documentation: Control over UART options. The InvertRX option controls invert of the receive pin. The InvertTX option controls invert of the transmit pin. The HalfDuplex option controls half-duplex (onewire) mode, where both transmit and receive is done on the transmit wire. The Swap option allows the RX and TX pins to be swapped on STM32F7 based boards. NOTE that two bits have moved from this parameter into MAVn_OPTIONS!

bitmask.bit: Don't forward mavlink to/from (moved to MAVn_OPTIONS >4.7)

param.field: 0:InvertRX, 1:InvertTX, 2:HalfDuplex, 3:SwapTXRX, 4: RX_PullDown, 5: RX_PullUp, 6: TX_PullDown, 7: TX_PullUp, 8: RX_NoDMA, 9: TX_NoDMA, 10: Don't forward mavlink to/from (moved to MAVn_OPTIONS >4.7), 11: DisableFIFO, 12: Ignore Streamrate (moved to MAVn_OPTIONS >4.7)

The HalfDuplex option controls half-duplex (onewire) mode, where both transmit and receive is done on the transmit wire. The Swap option allows the RX and TX pins to be swapped on STM32F7 based boards. NOTE that two bits have moved from this parameter into MAVn_OPTIONS!

bitmask.bit: Don't forward mavlink to/from (moved to MAVn_OPTIONS >4.7)

param.name: SERIAL_PASS1
param.documentation: This sets one side of pass-through between two serial ports. Once both sides are set then all data received on either port will be passed to the other port

param.name: SERIAL_PASS2
param.documentation: This sets one side of pass-through between two serial ports. Once both sides are set then all data received on either port will be passed to the other port. This parameter is normally reset to -1 on reboot, disabling passthrough. If SERIAL_PASSTIMO is set to -1 then it is not reset on reboot.

param.name: SERIAL_PASSTIMO
param.documentation: This sets a timeout for serial pass-through in seconds. When the pass-through is enabled by setting the SERIAL_PASS1 and SERIAL_PASS2 parameters then it remains in effect until no data comes from the first port for SERIAL_PASSTIMO seconds. This allows the port to revent to its normal usage (such as MAVLink connection to a GCS) when it is no longer needed. A value of 0 means no timeout. A value of -1 means no timeout and the SERIAL_PASS2 parameter is not reset on reboot.

param.name: SERVO_RATE
param.documentation: Default output rate in Hz for all PWM outputs.

param.name: SERVO_DSHOT_RATE
param.documentation: DShot output rate for all outputs as a multiple of the loop rate. 0 sets the output rate to be fixed at 1Khz for low loop rates. This value should never be set below 500Hz.

param.name: SERVO_DSHOT_ESC
param.documentation: DShot ESC type for all outputs. The ESC type affects the range of DShot commands available and the bit widths used. None means that no dshot commands will be executed. Some ESC types support Extended DShot Telemetry (EDT) which allows telemetry other than RPM data to be returned when using bi-directional dshot. If you enable EDT you must install EDT capable firmware for correct operation.

param.name: SERVO_GPIO_MASK
param.documentation: Bitmask of outputs which will be available as GPIOs. Any output with either the function set to -1 or with the corresponding bit set in this mask will be available for use as a GPIO pin

param.name: SERVO_RC_FS_MSK
param.documentation: Bitmask of scaled passthru output channels which will be set to their trim value during rc failsafe instead of holding their last position before failsafe.

param.name: SERVO_32_ENABLE
param.documentation: This allows for up to 32 outputs, enabling parameters for outputs above 16

param.name: SERVO1_MIN
param.documentation: minimum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: SERVO1_MAX
param.documentation: maximum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: SERVO1_TRIM
param.documentation: Trim PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: SERVO1_REVERSED
param.documentation: Reverse servo operation. Set to 0 for normal operation. Set to 1 to reverse this output channel.

param.name: SERVO1_FUNCTION
param.documentation: Function assigned to this servo. Setting this to Disabled(0) will setup this output for control by auto missions or MAVLink servo set commands. any other value will enable the corresponding function

param.name: SERVO2_MIN
param.documentation: minimum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: SERVO2_MAX
param.documentation: maximum PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: SERVO2_TRIM
param.documentation: Trim PWM pulse width in microseconds. Typically 1000 is lower limit, 1500 is neutral and 2000 is upper limit.

param.name: SERVO2_REVERSED
param.documentation: Reverse servo operation. Set to 0 for normal operation. Set to 1 to reverse this output channel.

param.name: SERVO2_FUNCTION
param.documentation: Function assigned to this servo. Setting this to Disabled(0) will setup this output for control by auto missions or MAVLink servo set commands. any other value will enable the corresponding function

param.name: SERVO_BLH_MASK
param.documentation: Enable of BLHeli pass-thru servo protocol support to specific channels. This mask is in addition to motors enabled using SERVO_BLH_AUTO (if any)
param.field: 0:Channel1,1:Channel2,2:Channel3,3:Channel4,4:Channel5,5:Channel6,6:Channel7,7:Channel8,8:Channel9,9:Channel10,10:Channel11,11:Channel12,12:Channel13,13:Channel14,14:Channel15,15:Channel16, 16:Channel 17, 17: Channel 18, 18: Channel 19, 19: Channel 20, 20: Channel 21, 21: Channel 22, 22: Channel 23, 23: Channel 24, 24: Channel 25, 25: Channel 26, 26: Channel 27, 27: Channel 28, 28: Channel 29, 29: Channel 30, 30: Channel 31, 31: Channel 32

param.humanName: BLHeli pass-thru auto-enable for multicopter motors
param.name: SERVO_BLH_AUTO
param.documentation: If set to 1 this auto-enables BLHeli pass-thru support for all multicopter motors

param.name: SERVO_BLH_TEST
param.documentation: Setting SERVO_BLH_TEST to a motor number enables an internal test of the BLHeli ESC protocol to the corresponding ESC. The debug output is displayed on the USB console.

param.name: SERVO_BLH_TMOUT
param.documentation: This sets the inactivity timeout for the BLHeli protocol in seconds. If no packets are received in this time normal MAVLink operations are resumed. A value of 0 means no timeout

param.name: SERVO_BLH_TRATE
param.documentation: This sets the rate in Hz for requesting telemetry from ESCs. It is the rate per ESC. Setting to zero disables telemetry requests

param.name: SERVO_BLH_DEBUG
param.documentation: When set to 1 this enabled verbose debugging output over MAVLink when the blheli protocol is active. This can be used to diagnose failures.

param.name: SERVO_BLH_OTYPE
param.documentation: When set to a non-zero value this overrides the output type for the output channels given by SERVO_BLH_MASK. This can be used to enable DShot on outputs that are not part of the multicopter motors group.

param.name: SERVO_BLH_PORT
param.documentation: This sets the mavlink channel to use for blheli pass-thru. The channel number is determined by the number of serial ports configured to use mavlink. So 0 is always the console, 1 is the next serial port using mavlink, 2 the next after that and so on.

param.name: SERVO_BLH_POLES
param.documentation: This allows calculation of true RPM from ESC's eRPM. The default is 14.

param.name: SERVO_BLH_3DMASK
param.documentation: Mask of channels which are dynamically reversible. This is used to configure ESCs in '3D' mode, allowing for the motor to spin in either direction. Note that setting an ESC as reversible with this option on AM32 will result in the forward direction of the ESC changing. You can combine with parameter with the SERVO_BLH_RVMASK parameter to maintain the same direction when the ESC is in 3D mode as it has in unidirectional (non-3D) mode.
param.field: 0:Channel1,1:Channel2,2:Channel3,3:Channel4,4:Channel5,5:Channel6,6:Channel7,7:Channel8,8:Channel9,9:Channel10,10:Channel11,11:Channel12,12:Channel13,13:Channel14,14:Channel15,15:Channel16, 16:Channel 17, 17: Channel 18, 18: Channel 19, 19: Channel 20, 20: Channel 21, 21: Channel 22, 22: Channel 23, 23: Channel 24, 24: Channel 25, 25: Channel 26, 26: Channel 27, 27: Channel 28, 28: Channel 29, 29: Channel 30, 30: Channel 31, 31: Channel 32

param.humanName: BLHeli bitmask of bi-directional dshot channels
param.name: SERVO_BLH_BDMASK
param.documentation: Mask of channels which support bi-directional dshot telemetry. This is used for ESCs which have firmware that supports bi-directional dshot allowing fast rpm telemetry values to be returned for the harmonic notch.
param.field: 0:Channel1,1:Channel2,2:Channel3,3:Channel4,4:Channel5,5:Channel6,6:Channel7,7:Channel8,8:Channel9,9:Channel10,10:Channel11,11:Channel12,12:Channel13,13:Channel14,14:Channel15,15:Channel16, 16:Channel 17, 17: Channel 18, 18: Channel 19, 19: Channel 20, 20: Channel 21, 21: Channel 22, 22: Channel 23, 23: Channel 24, 24: Channel 25, 25: Channel 26, 26: Channel 27, 27: Channel 28, 28: Channel 29, 29: Channel 30, 30: Channel 31, 31: Channel 32

param.name: SERVO_BLH_RVMASK
param.documentation: Mask of channels which are reversed. This is used to configure ESCs to reverse motor direction. Note that when combined with SERVO_BLH_3DMASK this will change what direction is considered to be forward.
param.field: 0:Channel1,1:Channel2,2:Channel3,3:Channel4,4:Channel5,5:Channel6,6:Channel7,7:Channel8,8:Channel9,9:Channel10,10:Channel11,11:Channel12,12:Channel13,13:Channel14,14:Channel15,15:Channel16, 16:Channel 17, 17: Channel 18, 18: Channel 19, 19: Channel 20, 20: Channel 21, 21: Channel 22, 22: Channel 23, 23: Channel 24, 24: Channel 25, 25: Channel 26, 26: Channel 27, 27: Channel 28, 28: Channel 29, 29: Channel 30, 30: Channel 31, 31: Channel 32

param.name: SERVO_FTW_MASK
param.documentation: Servo channel mask specifying FETtec ESC output.

param.name: SERVO_FTW_RVMASK
param.documentation: Servo channel mask to reverse rotation of FETtec ESC outputs.

param.name: SERVO_FTW_POLES
param.documentation: Number of motor electrical poles

param.name: SERVO_ROB_POSMIN
param.documentation: Position minimum at servo min value. This should be within the position control range of the servos, normally 0 to 4095

param.name: SERVO_ROB_POSMAX
param.documentation: Position maximum at servo max value. This should be within the position control range of the servos, normally 0 to 4095

param.name: SERVO_SBUS_RATE
param.documentation: This sets the SBUS output frame rate in Hz.

param.name: SERVO_VOLZ_MASK
param.documentation: Enable of volz servo protocol to specific channels

param.name: SERVO_VOLZ_RANGE
param.documentation: Range to map between 1000 and 2000 PWM. Default value of 200 gives full +-100 deg range of extended position command. This results in 0.2 deg movement per US change in PWM. If the full range is not needed it can be reduced to increase resolution. 40 deg range gives 0.04 deg movement per US change in PWM, this is higher resolution than possible with the VOLZ protocol so further reduction in range will not improve resolution. Reduced range does allow PWMs outside the 1000 to 2000 range, with 40 deg range 750 PWM results in a angle of -30 deg, 2250 would be +30 deg. This is still limited by the 200 deg maximum range of the actuator.

param.name: STAT_BOOTCNT
param.documentation: Number of times board has been booted

param.name: STAT_FLTTIME
param.documentation: Total FlightTime (seconds)

param.name: STAT_RUNTIME
param.documentation: Total time autopilot has run

param.name: STAT_RESET
param.documentation: Seconds since January 1st 2016 (Unix epoch+1451606400) since statistics reset (set to 0 to reset statistics, other set values will be ignored)

param.name: STAT_FLTCNT
param.documentation: Total number of flights

param.name: STAT_DISTFLWN
param.documentation: Estimate of total distance flown since statistics reset

param.name: TEMP_LOG
param.documentation: Enables temperature sensor logging

values.value: Log only instances with sensor source set to None

param.name: TEMP1_TYPE
param.documentation: Enables temperature sensors

param.name: TEMP1_BUS
param.documentation: Temperature sensor bus number, typically used to select from multiple I2C buses

param.name: TEMP1_ADDR
param.documentation: Temperature sensor address, typically used for I2C address

param.name: TEMP1_SRC
param.documentation: Sensor Source is used to designate which device's temperature report will be replaced by this temperature sensor's data. If 0 (None) then the data is only available via log. In the future a new Motor temperature report will be created for returning data directly.

param.name: TEMP1_SRC_ID
param.documentation: Sensor Source Identification is used to replace a specific instance of a system component's temperature report with the temp sensor's. Examples: TEMP_SRC = 1 (ESC), TEMP_SRC_ID = 1 will set the temp of ESC1. TEMP_SRC = 3 (BatteryIndex),TEMP_SRC_ID = 2 will set the temp of BATT2. TEMP_SRC = 4 (BatteryId/SerialNum),TEMP_SRC_ID=42 will set the temp of all batteries that have param BATTn_SERIAL = 42.

param.humanName: Temperature sensor analog voltage sensing pin
param.name: TEMP1_PIN
param.documentation: Sets the analog input pin that should be used for temprature monitoring. Values for some autopilots are given as examples. Search wiki for "Analog pins".

param.name: TEMP1_A0
param.documentation: a0 in polynomial of form temperature in deg = a0 + a1*voltage + a2*voltage^2 + a3*voltage^3 + a4*voltage^4 + a5*voltage^5

param.name: TEMP1_A1
param.documentation: a1 in polynomial of form temperature in deg = a0 + a1*voltage + a2*voltage^2 + a3*voltage^3 + a4*voltage^4 + a5*voltage^5

param.name: TEMP1_A2
param.documentation: a2 in polynomial of form temperature in deg = a0 + a1*voltage + a2*voltage^2 + a3*voltage^3 + a4*voltage^4 + a5*voltage^5

param.name: TEMP1_A3
param.documentation: a3 in polynomial of form temperature in deg = a0 + a1*voltage + a2*voltage^2 + a3*voltage^3 + a4*voltage^4 + a5*voltage^5

param.name: TEMP1_A4
param.documentation: a4 in polynomial of form temperature in deg = a0 + a1*voltage + a2*voltage^2 + a3*voltage^3 + a4*voltage^4 + a5*voltage^5

param.name: TEMP1_A5
param.documentation: a5 in polynomial of form temperature in deg = a0 + a1*voltage + a2*voltage^2 + a3*voltage^3 + a4*voltage^4 + a5*voltage^5

param.name: TEMP1_MSG_ID
param.documentation: Sets the message device ID this backend listens for

param.name: TEMP1_RTD_NOM
param.documentation: Nominal RTD resistance used to calculate temperature, typically 100 or 1000 ohms.

param.name: TEMP1_RTD_REF
param.documentation: Reference resistance used to calculate temperature, in ohms

param.name: TEMP10_TYPE
param.documentation: Enables temperature sensors

param.name: TEMP10_BUS
param.documentation: Temperature sensor bus number, typically used to select from multiple I2C buses

param.name: TEMP10_ADDR
param.documentation: Temperature sensor address, typically used for I2C address

param.name: TEMP10_SRC
param.documentation: Sensor Source is used to designate which device's temperature report will be replaced by this temperature sensor's data. If 0 (None) then the data is only available via log. In the future a new Motor temperature report will be created for returning data directly.

param.name: TEMP10_SRC_ID
param.documentation: Sensor Source Identification is used to replace a specific instance of a system component's temperature report with the temp sensor's. Examples: TEMP_SRC = 1 (ESC), TEMP_SRC_ID = 1 will set the temp of ESC1. TEMP_SRC = 3 (BatteryIndex),TEMP_SRC_ID = 2 will set the temp of BATT2. TEMP_SRC = 4 (BatteryId/SerialNum),TEMP_SRC_ID=42 will set the temp of all batteries that have param BATTn_SERIAL = 42.

param.name: VISO_TYPE
param.documentation: Visual odometry camera connection type

param.humanName: Visual odometry camera X position offset
param.name: VISO_POS_X
param.documentation: X position of the camera in body frame. Positive X is forward of the origin.

param.humanName: Visual odometry camera Y position offset
param.name: VISO_POS_Y
param.documentation: Y position of the camera in body frame. Positive Y is to the right of the origin.

param.humanName: Visual odometry camera Z position offset
param.name: VISO_POS_Z
param.documentation: Z position of the camera in body frame. Positive Z is down from the origin.

param.name: VISO_ORIENT
param.documentation: Visual odometery camera orientation

param.name: VISO_SCALE
param.documentation: Visual odometry scaling factor applied to position estimates from sensor

param.name: VISO_DELAY_MS
param.documentation: Visual odometry sensor delay relative to inertial measurements

param.name: VISO_VEL_M_NSE
param.documentation: Visual odometry velocity measurement noise in m/s

param.name: VISO_POS_M_NSE
param.documentation: Visual odometry position measurement noise minimum (meters). This value will be used if the sensor provides a lower noise value (or no noise value)

param.name: VISO_YAW_M_NSE
param.documentation: Visual odometry yaw measurement noise minimum (radians), This value will be used if the sensor provides a lower noise value (or no noise value)

param.name: VISO_QUAL_MIN
param.documentation: Visual odometry will only be sent to EKF if over this value. -1 to always send (even bad values), 0 to send if good or unknown

param.humanName: Is the Video Transmitter enabled or not
param.name: VTX_ENABLE
param.documentation: Toggles the Video Transmitter on and off

param.name: VTX_POWER
param.documentation: Video Transmitter Power Level. Different VTXs support different power levels, the power level chosen will be rounded down to the nearest supported power level

param.name: VTX_CHANNEL
param.documentation: Video Transmitter Channel

param.name: VTX_BAND
param.documentation: Video Transmitter Band

param.name: VTX_FREQ
param.documentation: Video Transmitter Frequency. The frequency is derived from the setting of BAND and CHANNEL

param.name: VTX_OPTIONS
param.documentation: Video Transmitter Options. Pitmode puts the VTX in a low power state. Unlocked enables certain restricted frequencies and power levels. Do not enable the Unlocked option unless you have appropriate permissions in your jurisdiction to transmit at high power levels. One stop-bit may be required for VTXs that erroneously mimic iNav behaviour.

bitmask.bit: Add leading zero byte to requests
Ignore status updates in CRSF and blindly set VTX options

param.field: 0:Pitmode,1:Pitmode until armed,2:Pitmode when disarmed,3:Unlocked,4:Add leading zero byte to requests,5:Use 1 stop-bit in SmartAudio,6:Ignore CRC in SmartAudio,7:Ignore status updates in CRSF and blindly set VTX options

param.name: VTX_MAX_POWER
param.documentation: Video Transmitter Maximum Power Level. Different VTXs support different power levels, this prevents the power aux switch from requesting too high a power level. The switch supports 6 power levels and the selected power will be a subdivision between 0 and this setting.
